source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Below 425 K [3], hydrides have an embrittling effect when they are perpendicular to the tensile axis [4]

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Extruded tubes usually have the majority of grains oriented with their basal-plane normals close to the circumferential direction [7].

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: To rotate these basal-plane normals close to the radial direction and to obtain a low D_ε P parameter, the extruded tube must be cold worked so that the wall thickness is reduced more than the circumference.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: The higher the ratio the larger is the proportion of grains oriented with their basal-plane normals close to the radial direction.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Hobson [10] showed that the cross-sectional shape of fuel sheathing after axial tensile deformation was related to the uniformity of the texture.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Fuel sheathing that had a square shape after axial tensile deformation had four peaks in the intensity of the basal-plane normals around the circumference of the tube, Fig. 6.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Tenkhoff and Rittenhouse [11] found variations in texture through the wall thickness which depended on the Q ratio, Fig. 7.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Hence, if the Q ratio is too high, the tubes could have variations in texture through the wall which would produce variations in mechanical properties and hydride orientation.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: The final stress-relieving treatment controls the combination of strength and ductility.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: The temperature and time must be chosen carefully, particularly for heavily cold-worked tubes, because a small difference in temperature can have a large effect on the tensile properties, Fig. 8.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: The effect of heating for 1 h on the tensile properties of tube reduced Zircaloy-2 fuel sheathing.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Tubes (round, oval or square) with wall thicknesses of 1 to 2 mm are used to guide coolant flow and control rods in pressurized water reactors (PWR) and pressure tube reactors for adjuster rod guides, Fig. 9, and calandria tubes, Fig. 10.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: It is difficult to extrude thin-walled zirconium alloy tubes with diameter to wall thickness ratios greater than 50:1 that have less than 10 percent variation in wall thickness around the circumference.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: However, 1 mm-thick sheet can be fabricated to tolerances of ± 0.05 mm on thickness, and this tolerance can be maintained through tube forming and seam welding operations.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Many Zircaloy-2 tubes are fabricated by this method.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Zr-2.5Nb tubes also can be fabricated by this technique, but after irradiation the ductility of the weld and the heat affected zones is lower than in Zircaloy-2.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: For Zircaloy-2, the heat input, welding speed, and seam leveling operations can be controlled so that when annealed the weld and heat affected zones recrystallize to produce a small grain size which has good ductility, Fig. 12.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: when Zr-2.5Nb is cooled rapidly from the $\beta$ phase $( > 1 2 2 5 \ \mathbf { K } )$ and then irradiated, the ductility is low
specimen_state: cooled rapidly from beta phase (>1225 K), irradiated

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: subsequent aging treatments in the $( \alpha + \beta \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b } )$ phase or in the $\mathrm { ( } \alpha \mathrm { ~ + ~ } \beta { \bf Z } \mathrm { \bf { r } } )$ phase do not improve the irradiated ductility
specimen_state: aged in (α+βNb) phase or (α+βZr) phase, irradiated

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: welds and heat affected zones in seam welded $\mathbf { Z r { - } } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N b }$ tubes have low ductility after irradiation
